column1: Where would be a good place to buy a camera?
column2: どこでカメラを<ruby>買<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ったらいいですか。
column3: InterrogativeVた-formらいいですか

column1: You can just go directly there.
column2: <ruby>直接<rp>(</rp><rt>ちょくせつ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>言<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ったらいいですよ。
column3: InterrogativeVた-formらいいですか

column1: I don't like karaoke.
column2: カラオケは<ruby>好<rp>(</rp><rt>す</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きじゃないんです。
column3:
N(object)は好きです・嫌いですN
上手です・下手です
あります, etc.
column4: Making a direct object marked by を was introduced in Lesson 17 of Book 1. Nounds indicated by が that are the object of phrases such as 好きです can also be made into a topic.

column1: I can speak Japanese.
column2: <ruby>日本語<rp>(</rp><rt>にほんご</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>話<rp>(</rp><rt>はな</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>せます。
column4: Indicate states, not actions.

column1: You can see Mount Fuji from the Shinkansen.
column2: <ruby>新幹線<rp>(</rp><rt>しんかんせん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>原<rp>(</rp><rt>げん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>富士山<rp>(</rp><rt>ふじさん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えます。
column3: 見えますand聞こえます
column4: 見えます and 聞こえます are not volitional; they denote something (indicated by が) naturally coming into sight, or a sound naturally reaching one's ears, independent of ome's will.

column1: The sound of a radio can be heard.
column2: ラジオの<ruby>音<rp>(</rp><rt>おと</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>聞<rp>(</rp><rt>き</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>こえます。
column3: 見えますand聞こえます
column4: 見えます and 聞こえます are not volitional; they denote something (indicated by が) naturally coming into sight, or a sound naturally reaching one's ears, independent of ome's will.

column1: A big supermarket was built in front of the station.
column2: <ruby>駅<rp>(</rp><rt>えき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>前<rp>(</rp><rt>まえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>大<rp>(</rp><rt>おお</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きいスーパーができました。
column3: できます
column4: The sense of the verb できます introduced here is to 'come into being', 'be finished, 'be made', etc.

column1: When can you repair this watch by?
column2: <ruby>時計<rp>(</rp><rt>とけい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>修理<rp>(</rp><rt>しゅうり</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>はいつできますか。
column3: できます
column4: The sense of the verb できます introduced here is to 'come into being', 'be finished, 'be made', etc.

column1: I can only write Romaji.
column2: ローマ<ruby>字<rp>(</rp><rt>じ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>しか、<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>けません。
column3: しか
column4: しか is appended to nouns, quantifiers, etc., and is always used with a negative. A sentence that contains it negates everything except the word to which it is attached. When used with a noun to which a particle is attached, it is appended to the particle unless this is が or を, which it replaces. It suggests insufficiency or inadequacy.

column1: I can write romaji [but nothing else]
column2: ローマ<ruby>字<rp>(</rp><rt>じ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>だけ<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>けます。
column3: しか
column4: しか is appended to nouns, quantifiers, etc., and is always used with a negative. A sentence that contains it negates everything except the word to which it is attached. When used with a noun to which a particle is attached, it is appended to the particle unless this is が or を, which it replaces. It suggests insufficiency or inadequacy.

column1: I drink wine, but I don't drink beer.
column2: ワインは<ruby>飲<rp>(</rp><rt>の</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みますが、ビールは<ruby>飲<rp>(</rp><rt>の</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みません。
column3: Nは(contrast)
column4: In addition to introducing a topic, は can also be used to indicate a contrast.

column1: The mountains were visible yesterday, but not today.
column2: <ruby>昨日<rp>(</rp><rt>きのう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は<ruby>山<rp>(</rp><rt>やま</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えましたが、<ruby>今日<rp>(</rp><rt>きょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えません。
column3: Nは(contrast)
column4: In addition to introducing a topic, は can also be used to indicate a contrast.

column1: You can't see any horses in Japan (See Lesson 18)
column2: <ruby>日本<rp>(</rp><rt>にっぽん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>では<ruby>馬<rp>(</rp><rt>うま</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ることができません。
column4: As explained in Book 1 Article 1 (p.160), when は is used with a noun to which another particle is already attached, it is appended to the particle unless the particle is が or を, which it replaces.

column1: On a fine day, you can see the sea.
column2: <ruby>天気<rp>(</rp><rt>てんき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>良<rp>(</rp><rt>よ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>い<ruby>日<rp>(</rp><rt>ひ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>には<ruby>海<rp>(</rp><rt>うみ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えるんです。
column4: As explained in Book 1 Article 1 (p.160), when は is used with a noun to which another particle is already attached, it is appended to the particle unless the particle is が or を, which it replaces.

column1: You can't see Tokyo Sky Tree from here.
column2: ここからはと<ruby>今日<rp>(</rp><rt>きょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>スカイツリーが<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えません。
column4: As explained in Book 1 Article 1 (p.160), when は is used with a noun to which another particle is already attached, it is appended to the particle unless the particle is が or を, which it replaces.

column1: I listen to music while eating.
column2: <ruby>音楽<rp>(</rp><rt>おんがく</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>聴<rp>(</rp><rt>き</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きながら<ruby>食事<rp>(</rp><rt>しょくじ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>します。
column3: V₁ます-formながらV₂
column4: This sentence pattern indicates that someone performing an action indicated by V1 is simultaneously performing a separate action indiated by V2, where V2 indicates the main action.

column1: I'm working while studying Japanese.
column2: <ruby>働<rp>(</rp><rt>はたら</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きながら<ruby>日本語<rp>(</rp><rt>にほんご</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>勉強<rp>(</rp><rt>べんきょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>しています。
column3: V₁ます-formながらV₂
column4: This sentence pattern indicates that someone performing an action indicated by V1 is simultaneously performing a separate action indiated by V2, where V2 indicates the main action.

column1: I go jogging every morning.
column2: <ruby>毎朝<rp>(</rp><rt>まいあさ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ジョギングをしています。
column3: Vて-formいます
column4: As well as indicating what someone is doing now, this sentence pattern can also be used to indicate a habitual behavior. Such a behavior is taking place in the past is indicated by Vて-form　いました。

column1: When was a child, I used to go to bed at eight every evening
column2: <ruby>子供<rp>(</rp><rt>こども</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>時<rp>(</rp><rt>とき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>、<ruby>毎晩<rp>(</rp><rt>まいばん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>８<ruby>時<rp>(</rp><rt>じ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>寝<rp>(</rp><rt>ね</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ていました。
column3: Vて-formいます
column4: As well as indicating what someone is doing now, this sentence pattern can also be used to indicate a habitual behavior. Such a behavior is taking place in the past is indicated by Vて-form　いました。

column1: Mr. Suzuki can play the piano, sing, and dance.
column2: <ruby>鈴木<rp>(</rp><rt>すずき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>さんはピアノも<ruby>弾<rp>(</rp><rt>はじ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>けるし、<ruby>歌<rp>(</rp><rt>うた</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>歌<rp>(</rp><rt>うた</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えるし、ダンスもできます。
column3: Plain formし、Plain formし、〜
column4: This pattern is used when mentioning two or more similar things one after the other about the topic. In the following example, the things mentioned are similar because they are accomplishments.

column1: Mr. Tanaka is serious, speaks good Chinese, and also has experience.
column2: <ruby>田中<rp>(</rp><rt>たなか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>さんは<ruby>真面目<rp>(</rp><rt>まじめ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>だし、<ruby>中国<rp>(</rp><rt>ちゅうごく</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>語<rp>(</rp><rt>ご</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>上手<rp>(</rp><rt>じょうず</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>だし、それに<ruby>経験<rp>(</rp><rt>けいけん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>もあります。
column3: Plain formし、Plain formし、〜
column4: This pattern is used when mentioning two or more similar things one after the other about the topic. In the following example, the things mentioned are similar because they are accomplishments.

column1: The prices are low here and the fish is fresh, so I often come here to eat.
column2: ここは<ruby>値段<rp>(</rp><rt>ねだん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>安<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いし、<ruby>魚<rp>(</rp><rt>さかな</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>新<rp>(</rp><rt>あたら</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>しいし、よく<ruby>食<rp>(</rp><rt>た</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>べにきます。
column3: Plain formし、Plain formし、〜
column4: This sentence pattern can also be used when the 〜し、〜し part gives the reasons for what follows. The conclusion may be omitted if it is obvious. The final し may also be replaced with から in its 'because' sense.

column1: Because the stories are interesting and I like the music.
column2: <ruby>話<rp>(</rp><rt>はなし</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>面白<rp>(</rp><rt>おもしろ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いし、<ruby>音楽<rp>(</rp><rt>おんがく</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>も<ruby>素敵<rp>(</rp><rt>すてき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ですから。
column3: Plain formし、Plain formし、〜
column4: This sentence pattern can also be used when the 〜し、〜し part gives the reasons for what follows. The conclusion may be omitted if it is obvious. The final し may also be replaced with から in its 'because' sense.

column1: I want to be a novelist, so now I'm writing a novel and working part-time while doing so.
column2: <ruby>将来<rp>(</rp><rt>しょうらい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>小説<rp>(</rp><rt>しょうせつ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>家<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>になりたいです。それで<ruby>今<rp>(</rp><rt>いま</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>はアルバイトをしながら<ruby>小説<rp>(</rp><rt>しょうせつ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いています。
column3: それで
column4: The sense is "because of this,". それで indicates that what is about to be said follows from what has just been said.

column1: I don't listen to music when I'm studying.
column2: <ruby>勉強<rp>(</rp><rt>べんきょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>するときは、<ruby>音楽<rp>(</rp><rt>おんがく</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>聞<rp>(</rp><rt>き</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きません。
column3: 〜とき\+particle
column4: Since the とき explained in lesson 23 is a noun, it can be used with a particle appended to it.

column1: The window is broken.
column2: <ruby>窓<rp>(</rp><rt>まど</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>割<rp>(</rp><rt>わ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>れています。
column3: Vて-formいます
column4: Another way of using Vて-form います is to show that the state resulting from the action indicated by the verb is still continuing.

column1: The light is on.
column2: <ruby>電気<rp>(</rp><rt>でんき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がついています。
column3: Vて-formいます
column4: Another way of using Vて-form います is to show that the state resulting from the action indicated by the verb is still continuing.

column1: I went and lost my passport.
column2: パスポートを<ruby>無<rp>(</rp><rt>な</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>くしてしまいました。
column3: Vて-formしまいました/しまいます
column4: 〜て しまいました emphasises that anaction has been completed. It may also indicate a feeling of regret or dissapointment. 〜て しまいます indicates that an action will be completed at some point in the future.

column1: Oh dear. We must go to the police box right away.
column2: それは<ruby>大変<rp>(</rp><rt>たいへん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ですね。<ruby>交番<rp>(</rp><rt>こうばん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>かないと。
column3: N(place)に行きます/来ます/帰ります
column4: The particle に (indicating an arrival point) is used instead of the particle へ (indicating a direction). Verbs such as 行きます、来ます、and 帰ります can be used with either particle in this way.

column1: Congratulations (for that thing you just told me)!
column2: それはおめでとうございます。
column3: それ/その/そう
column4: Lesson 2 demonstrated how to use demonstratives to point to something tangible. The present lesson introduces the use of these to indicate something appearing in speech or writing.

column1: ... yes, I will (do that thing you just told me to.)
column2: そう　します
column3: それ/その/そう
column4: Lesson 2 demonstrated how to use demonstratives to point to something tangible. The present lesson introduces the use of these to indicate something appearing in speech or writing.

column1: Here's your bag!
column2: かばんがありましたよ。
column3: ありました
column4: This can indicate that the speaker has just found something.

column1: Is there a phone around here?
column2: とこかに<ruby>電話<rp>(</rp><rt>でんわ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がありますか。
column3: どこかで/どこかに
column4: The particle へ or を after とこか or 何か can be omitted, but the particle で or に cannot.

column1: I've gone and lost my wallet somewhere.
column2: どこかで<ruby>財布<rp>(</rp><rt>さいふ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>をなくしてしまいました。
column3: どこかで/どこかに
column4: The particle へ or を after とこか or 何か can be omitted, but the particle で or に cannot.

column1: Someone's left a note on the desk.
column2: <ruby>机<rp>(</rp><rt>つくえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>上<rp>(</rp><rt>うえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>にメモが<ruby>置<rp>(</rp><rt>お</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いてあります。
column3: N₁ に N₂ が Vて-form あります
column4: This indicates a continuing state resulting from a purposeful action. Transitive verbs are used for this.

column1: Where's the note? [The note is] on the desk.
column2: メモはどこですか。メモは<ruby>机<rp>(</rp><rt>つくえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>上<rp>(</rp><rt>うえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>置<rp>(</rp><rt>お</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いてあります。
column3: N₂ は N₁ に Vて-form あります
column4: When N₂ is taken as the topic, it is indicated by the particle は.

column1: I'll buy my tickets before travelling.
column2: <ruby>旅行<rp>(</rp><rt>りょこう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>前<rp>(</rp><rt>まえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に、<ruby>切符<rp>(</rp><rt>きっぷ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>買<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っておきます。
column3: Vて-formおきます
column4: This can indicate that a neccessary action or behavior is to be performed by a certain time.

column1: Please read these documents (before the meeting)
column2: この<ruby>資料<rp>(</rp><rt>しりょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>読<rp>(</rp><rt>よ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>んでおいてください。
column3: Vて-formおきます
column4: This can indicate that a neccessary action or behavior is to be performed by a certain time.

column1: When you've finished using the scissors, please put them back where they were.
column2: ハサミを<ruby>使<rp>(</rp><rt>つか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ったら、<ruby>元<rp>(</rp><rt>もと</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>のところに<ruby>戻<rp>(</rp><rt>もど</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>しておいてください。
column3: Vて-formおきます
column4: It can indicate taking some temporary measures or completing a necessary action in preparation for the next time one uses something.

column1: There's a meeting here tomorrow, so please leave the chairs as they are.
column2: <ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>会議<rp>(</rp><rt>かいぎ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がありますから、いすはこのままにしておいてください。
column3: Vて-formおきます
column4: It indicates keeping a resultant state as it is.

column1: Please leave it there.
column2: そこに<ruby>置<rp>(</rp><rt>お</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いておいてください。
column3: Vて-formおきます
column4: It indicates keeping a resultant state as it is.

column1: It's still raining
column2: まだ<ruby>雨<rp>(</rp><rt>あめ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>降<rp>(</rp><rt>ふ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っています。
column3:
まだ\+affirmative
とか

column1: I'm still using (them), please leave them where they are.
column2: まだ<ruby>使<rp>(</rp><rt>つか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っていますから、そのままにしておいてください。
column3:
まだ\+affirmative
とか

column1: There are various other things as well.
column2: ほかにもいろいろあります。
column3: Particle\+も
column4: When も is attached to a noun to which が or を is already attached, it replaces these. When another particle (such as に, で, から, まで, or と) is already attached to the noun, that particle is left in place and も is appended to it. If the other particle is へ, then the も may either replace it or be appended to it.

column1: I'm not going anywhere.
column2: どこ[へ]も<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きません。
column3: Particle\+も
column4: When も is attached to a noun to which が or を is already attached, it replaces these. When another particle (such as に, で, から, まで, or と) is already attached to the noun, that particle is left in place and も is appended to it. If the other particle is へ, then the も may either replace it or be appended to it.

column1: ...yes, let's take a break (volitional)
column2: うん、<ruby>休<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>もう。
column4: In plain-style sentences as the plain form of 〜ましょう

column1: May I help? (volitional)
column2: <ruby>手伝<rp>(</rp><rt>てつだ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>おうか。
column4: In plain-style sentences as the plain form of 〜ましょう

column1: I'm thinking of going to the ocean on the weekend.
column2: <ruby>週末<rp>(</rp><rt>しゅうまつ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は<ruby>海<rp>(</rp><rt>うみ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>へ<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>こうと<ruby>思<rp>(</rp><rt>おも</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っています。
column3: V volitional-form と思っています
column4: Convey the speaker's intention to the listener.

column1: I think I'll go to the bank now.
column2: <ruby>今<rp>(</rp><rt>いま</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>から<ruby>銀行<rp>(</rp><rt>ぎんこう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>へ<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>こうと<ruby>思<rp>(</rp><rt>おも</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>います。
column3: V volitional-form と思っています
column4: Convey the speaker's intention to the listener.

column1: He's thinking of setting up a school.
column2: <ruby>彼<rp>(</rp><rt>かれ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は<ruby>学校<rp>(</rp><rt>がっこう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>作<rp>(</rp><rt>つく</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ろうと<ruby>思<rp>(</rp><rt>おも</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っています。
column3: V volitional-form と思っています
column4: Convey the speaker's intention to the listener.

column1: I intend to continue studying Japanese even after I have returned to my home country.
column2: <ruby>国<rp>(</rp><rt>くに</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>へ<ruby>帰<rp>(</rp><rt>かえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っても、<ruby>日本語<rp>(</rp><rt>にほんご</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>勉強<rp>(</rp><rt>べんきょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>続<rp>(</rp><rt>つづ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>けるつもりです。
column3:
V dictionary-formつもりです。
Vない-form ない
column4: V dictionary form つもりです expresses the speaker's intention to do something. To indicate an intention not to do something,Vない-form ない つもりです is usually used.

column1: I intend not to smoke from tomorrow on.
column2: <ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>からはタバコを<ruby>吸<rp>(</rp><rt>す</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>わないつもりです。
column3:
V dictionary-formつもりです。
Vない-form ない
column4: V dictionary form つもりです expresses the speaker's intention to do something. To indicate an intention not to do something,Vない-form ない つもりです is usually used.

column1: I plan to go to Germany on business at the end of July.
column2: <ruby>７月<rp>(</rp><rt>しちがつ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>の<ruby>終<rp>(</rp><rt>お</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>わりにドイツへ<ruby>出張<rp>(</rp><rt>しゅっちょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>する<ruby>予定<rp>(</rp><rt>よてい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>です。
column3:
V dictionary-formよています
Nの
column4: Stating something that one plans to do.

column1: The trip is scheduled to last for about a week.
column2: <ruby>旅行<rp>(</rp><rt>りょこう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は１<ruby>週間<rp>(</rp><rt>しゅうかん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ぐらいの<ruby>予定<rp>(</rp><rt>よてい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>です。
column3:
V dictionary-formよています
Nの
column4: Stating something that one plans to do.

column1: The bank isn't open yet.
column2: <ruby>銀行<rp>(</rp><rt>ぎんこう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がまだ<ruby>開<rp>(</rp><rt>ひら</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いていません。
column3: まだVて-formいません
column4: This expression indicates that a situation has not yet occurred, or something has not yet been done.

column1: ...no, I haven't written it yet.
column2: いいえ、まだ<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いていません。
column3: まだVて-formいません
column4: This expression indicates that a situation has not yet occurred, or something has not yet been done.

column1: Where do we get on the Shinkansenn to go back?
column2: <ruby>帰<rp>(</rp><rt>かえ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>りの<ruby>新幹線<rp>(</rp><rt>しんかんせん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>はどこから<ruby>乗<rp>(</rp><rt>の</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>りますか。
column3: 帰りますー帰り
column4: The same form as the ます-form can be used as a noun, as in the following examples.

column1: Which days do you have off?
column2: <ruby>休<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みは<ruby>何<rp>(</rp><rt>なに</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>曜日<rp>(</rp><rt>ようび</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ですか。
column3: 帰りますー帰り
column4: The same form as the ます-form can be used as a noun, as in the following examples.

column1: You'd better do some exercise every day.
column2: <ruby>毎日<rp>(</rp><rt>まいにち</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>運動<rp>(</rp><rt>うんどう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>した<ruby>方<rp>(</rp><rt>ほう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がいいです。
column3:
Vた-formほうがいいです
Vない-form ない
column4: This sentence pattern is used to make suggestions or give advice. It implies it would be bad not to not take the action specified by the verb. Be careful since this can make the speaker sound overbearing. When simply recommending a certain action, 〜たらいい (Lesson 26) is used. See 26-3

column1: In that case, you'd better not have a bath.
column2: じゃ、おふろに<ruby>入<rp>(</rp><rt>はい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>らない<ruby>方<rp>(</rp><rt>ほう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がいいですよ。
column3:
Vた-formほうがいいです
Vない-form ない
column4: This sentence pattern is used to make suggestions or give advice. It implies it would be bad not to not take the action specified by the verb. Be careful since this can make the speaker sound overbearing. When simply recommending a certain action, 〜たらいい (Lesson 26) is used. See 26-3

column1: It will probably rain tomorrow.
column2: <ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>は<ruby>雨<rp>(</rp><rt>あめ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>が<ruby>降<rp>(</rp><rt>ふ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>るでしょう。
column3:
Vplain-formでしょう
い-adj
な-adjplain-form
N
column4: 〜でしょう is used when a speaker wants to express an opinion about something in the future or something uncertain, without being definite.

column1: We might not get there in time for the appointment.
column2: やくそくの<ruby>時間<rp>(</rp><rt>じかん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>間<rp>(</rp><rt>ま</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>に<ruby>合<rp>(</rp><rt>あ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>わないかもしれません。
column3:
Vplain-formかもしれません
い-adj
な-adjplain-form
N
column4: 〜かもしれません can be used when the speaker wants to point out that there is a possibility, however small, of 〜.

column1: It might have broken. Let me check it out.
column2: <ruby>故障<rp>(</rp><rt>こしょう</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>かもしれません。ちょっと<ruby>調<rp>(</rp><rt>しら</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>べましょう。
column3: Vます-formましょう
column4: The Vます-form ましょう in the following example is an expression used to convey the speaker's intention to the listener, and is used when announcing an action. It has a more assertive tone than Vます-form ましょう.

column1: Can we get to the station in 30 minutes?
column2: <ruby>駅<rp>(</rp><rt>えき</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>まで３０ぷんで<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>けますか。
column3: Quantifierで
column4: This shows a time limit or another limit.

column1: Can you buy a PC for 30,000 yen?
column2: ３<ruby>万<rp>(</rp><rt>まん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>円<rp>(</rp><rt>えん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>でパソコンが<ruby>買<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えますか。
column3: Quantifierで
column4: This shows a time limit or another limit.

column1: Is there anything you're worried about?
column2: <ruby>何<rp>(</rp><rt>なに</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>か<ruby>心配<rp>(</rp><rt>しんぱい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>なことがあるんですか。
column3: 何か心配なこと

column1: Go to bed immedietly!
column2: <ruby>早<rp>(</rp><rt>はや</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>く<ruby>寝<rp>(</rp><rt>ね</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ろ
column4: Senior making a demand to a junior

column1: Come to my house tomorrow!
column2: <ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>うちへ<ruby>来<rp>(</rp><rt>こ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いよ
column4: Male friends demanding something (often softened with よ)

column1: Hey, don't drink too much!
column2: あまり<ruby>飲<rp>(</rp><rt>の</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>むな[よ]
column4: Male friends demanding something (often softened with よ)

column1: Run!
column2: <ruby>逃<rp>(</rp><rt>に</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>げろ
column4: Giving instructions when there is no time to be polite (e.g. earthquake)

column1: Don't use the lift!
column2: エレベーターを<ruby>使<rp>(</rp><rt>つか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>うな
column4: Giving instructions when there is no time to be polite (e.g. earthquake)

column1: 負けろな
column2: がんばれ
column4: Giving commands during group training, sports, etc...

column1: STOP
column2: <ruby>止<rp>(</rp><rt>と</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>まれ
column4: Notices when impact and brevity are required (e.g. traffic signs)

column1: NO ENTRY
column2: <ruby>入<rp>(</rp><rt>はい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>るな
column4: Notices when impact and brevity are required (e.g. traffic signs)

column1: How do you read that kanji?
column2: あの<ruby>感<rp>(</rp><rt>かん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>じはなんと<ruby>読<rp>(</rp><rt>よ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>むんですか。
column3: 〜と書いてあります/〜と読みます
column4: Like といいます but with different verbs.

column1: It says, "STOP" over there.
column2: あそこに「<ruby>止<rp>(</rp><rt>と</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>まれ」と<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いてあります。
column3: 〜と書いてあります/〜と読みます
column4: Like といいます but with different verbs.

column1: "Tachiiri Kinshi" means do not enter.
column2: 「<ruby>立<rp>(</rp><rt>た</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ち<ruby>入<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>り<ruby>禁止<rp>(</rp><rt>きんし</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>」は<ruby>入<rp>(</rp><rt>はい</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>るなといういみです。
column3: XはYといういみです
column4: This form is used when defining X. という comes from といいます. When inquiring as to the meaning of something, the interrogative どういう is used.

column1: What does this symbol/mark mean?
column2: このマークはどういういみですか。
column3: XはYといういみです
column4: This form is used when defining X. という comes from といいます. When inquiring as to the meaning of something, the interrogative どういう is used.

column1: Mr. Tanaka said, "I'm taking the day off tomorrow".
column2: <ruby>田中<rp>(</rp><rt>たなか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>さんは「<ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>休<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みです」と<ruby>言<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っていました。
column3:
Sと言っていました
plain-form
column4: 〜と言いました is used when quoting what someone said (See Lesson 21), while 〜と言っていました is used for reporting what someone said. The ています gives the sense of "was saying...."

column1: Mr. Tanaka said he would take the day off tomorrow.
column2: <ruby>田中<rp>(</rp><rt>たなか</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>さんは<ruby>明日<rp>(</rp><rt>あした</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby><ruby>休<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>むと<ruby>言<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>っていました。
column3:
Sと言っていました
plain-form
column4: 〜と言いました is used when quoting what someone said (See Lesson 21), while 〜と言っていました is used for reporting what someone said. The ています gives the sense of "was saying...."

column1: Would you mind asking Mr. Wang to call me later?
column2: ワンさんに「<ruby>後<rp>(</rp><rt>あと</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>で<ruby>電話<rp>(</rp><rt>でんわ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>をください」と<ruby>伝<rp>(</rp><rt>つた</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>えていただけませんか。
column3:
Sとつたえていただけませんか
plain-form
column4: This is used when the speaker is politly asking someone to pass a message on for him or her.

column1: Please do it as I did.
column2: <ruby>私<rp>(</rp><rt>わたし</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>がやってとおりに、やってください。
column3: V₁た-form とおりに、V₂
column4: Doing V2 by the same method or under the same condition as V1

column1: Please describe exactly what you saw.
column2: <ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>たとおりに<ruby>話<rp>(</rp><rt>はな</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>してください。
column3: V₁た-form とおりに、V₂
column4: Doing V2 by the same method or under the same condition as V1

column1: Please cut the paper along the line.
column2: せんのとおりに、<ruby>紙<rp>(</rp><rt>かみ</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>を<ruby>切<rp>(</rp><rt>き</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ってください。
column3: Nの とおりに、V
column4: Perform an action without deviating from the standard

column1: I assembled it according to the instructions.
column2: せつめいしょのとおりに、くみたてました。
column3: Nの とおりに、V
column4: Perform an action without deviating from the standard

column1: Please draw it like this.
column2: このとおりに、<ruby>書<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>いてください。
column3: Nの とおりに、V
column4: Perform an action without deviating from the standard

column1: After I bought a new one, the watch that I had lost was found.
column2: <ruby>新<rp>(</rp><rt>あたら</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>しいのを<ruby>買<rp>(</rp><rt>か</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>ったあとで、なくしたとけいが<ruby>見<rp>(</rp><rt>み</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>つかりました。
column3:
V₁た-formあとで、V₂
Nの
column4: Indicates that the action V2 happens after the action V1 or N

column1: Shall we go for a drink after work?
column2: しごとのあとで、<ruby>飲<rp>(</rp><rt>の</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みに<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>きませんか。
column3:
V₁た-formあとで、V₂
Nの
column4: Indicates that the action V2 happens after the action V1 or N

column1: We eat it with soy sauce.
column2: しょうゆをつけて<ruby>食<rp>(</rp><rt>た</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>べます。
column3:
V₁て-formV₂
V₁ない-form ないで
column4: Indicate that V1 is an action or state that accompanies V2

column1: We eat it without soy sauce.
column2: しょうゆをつけないで<ruby>食<rp>(</rp><rt>た</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>べます。
column3:
V₁て-formV₂
V₁ない-form ないで
column4: Indicate that V1 is an action or state that accompanies V2

column1: I'm not going anywhere on Sunday; I'm going to stay at home and take it easy.
column2: <ruby>日曜日<rp>(</rp><rt>にちようび</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>はどこも<ruby>行<rp>(</rp><rt>い</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>かないで、うちでゆっくり<ruby>休<rp>(</rp><rt>やす</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby>みます。
column3:
V₁て-formV₂
V₁ない-form ないで
column4: Indicate a decision to perform one or the other of two mutually-exclusive alternate actions.
